title: Friday, 4th December, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Neil Collins is with us today

NC

Good morning

11:01 am
PM

Bryce will be, later

PM

He had to make an unscheduled stop in Mayfair

PM

wink smile

11:01 am
NC

two and twenty?

PM

We're are going to go straight to macro grey this morning

PM

Yes, Neil, something like that

11:02 am
PM

To grey from Rabobank

PM

Farce-nancial markets, Farce-nancial times

PM

Mr. Draghi took out his bazooka yesterday and fired it into his own foot. It’s hard to believe the ECB
would have expected cutting the deposit rate 10bp to -0.30%, extending QE to March 2017,
reinvesting principal payments as they mature, and saying they will buy regional and local
government debt too, would result in EUR/USD surging from 1.0524 to 1.0944, a four big figure
move that rounds out a year of massive FX volatility nicely. They probably also would not have
expected 10-year Bund yields to jump 20bp on the day to 0.67% and Euro Stoxx to slump 3.6%. Yet
such was their achievement. (Please see more comprehensive coverage from our intrepid ECBologist,
Elwin de Groot.) Meanwhile, on what was already a “Believe it or Not” day in terms of
volatility, the Farce-nancial Times released the wrong ECB rate verdict on its website several minutes
early, before shame-facedly retracting.

Today is all about US payrolls. In light of the holiday period that we are in and the generally farcical
nature of markets at the moment, I would like to cover this topic in the form of a Christmas Carol.

PM

On the first month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 201K, OK you’ll agree;
On the second month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 266K and lots of glee;
On the third month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: just 119K, my knees were wobbly;
On the fourth month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 187K that made me happy;
On the fifth month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: two hun-dred and sixty kay, yippee!;
On the sixth month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: a 245K I was glad to see;
On the seventh month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 223K that kept me cozy;
On the eight month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: just 153K that made me crabby;
On the ninth month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 137K, and I spilled my tea;
On the tenth month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: 271K that made me dizzy;
On the eleventh month of payrolls, the BLS sent to me: ....we shall have to wait and see...

BE

Another indication that housebuilders don't really want to build houses.

NC

As you so frequently say, Bryce, it's not really worth their while

BE

So, cash on the balance sheet isn't being employed to do anything useful, such as building onto Berkeley's sizeable land bank.

11:12 am
PM

two quid a year divi promised thru to 2021

BE

It's just dropping straight to shareholders. Who, I guess, can buy a house with that cash.

BE

And so the plates keep spinning.

11:12 am
BE

Here's Davy to summarise what's been said.

BE

Berkeley’s previous dividend return plan would have likely led
to a large build-up of cash on its balance sheet and the
expansion of the plan will go some way to addressing this. The
additional £500m to be paid in the next six years will increase
the dividend yield to close to 6%.

BE

Berkeley Group has released (December 4 th ) H1 results to end-October which were
broadly in line with expectations. Revenue from operations increased by c.18%
compared to H1 2014/15, with volumes increasing from 1,372 to 2,091, partially offset
by lower mix in ASP, which fell from £649,000 to £506,000.
Operating profit fell by c.3% from £299.6m to £290.7m. Within this, there was an
exceptional profit made from the sale of ground rent assets which generated £51m of
profit. In the same period last year, there was an £85.1m profit on this. Stripping this
out, the operating profit from operations was £239.7m, up c.12% on the £214.5m
generated in H1 last year.

11:13 am
BE

Berkeley has observed a stable operating environment over the first six months of the
year, seeing sales prices increase in line with the wider market. Cash due on forward
sales over the next three years has increased to £3,096m from £2,959m.

BE

The company has expanded its Capital Return Plan which had originally been expected to
deliver £13.00 per share in dividends before September 2021. This has been increased to
£16.34, representing a further £500m of distributions. This leaves £12 remaining to be
paid over the period, and the company expects a flat dividend over this horizon,
suggesting a payment of £2.00 per share each year until 2021. This represents a dividend
yield of just under 6% based on last night’s closing price.

BE

Berkeley's the only housebuilder with real exposure to London, of course.

11:13 am

"Dividend yield close to 6%" Some of it is capital repayment, so not what I'd call "sustainable"

http://ftalphavill...n-for-just-1-375m/

11:16 am
PM

hehehe

BE

Anyway, have some Deutsche Bank too.

BE

With H1 16 PBT just over half of FY 16 ests, management reiterating FY16-18
PBT guidance and robust forward sales we see little to move consensus in
today’s results. The increased dividend will therefore take centre stage, and
while a 6% dividend yield will prove difficult to ignore, those wary of the
London market may still remain cautious of the stock. HOLD.
1) Dividend programme enhanced. Berkeley has updated its long term dividend
programme, upping the cash returns to shareholders from £13 to be returned
from 2011-2021 (with £4.34 already returned) to £16.34 over the same period.
This implies £2/share dividend pa will be paid from Sep 2016-21, rather than
144p previously indicated. That implies the stock yields approx 6% (which in a
FTSE100 context puts it in the top 10). However this remains only just ahead of
the 180p dividend the company annualized last year. Our forecasts at this time
(which include the 144p dividend), has the company sitting on approx £1bn of
cash by YE 2021 (after the dividend that would be payable for that year). The
updated dividend programme will pay out an additional £0.5bn, which suggests
a further 65p per year dividend could be paid (ie a further 2%). 2) H1 16 results,
ahead of DB but in line with FY 16 ests. Berkeley has reported H1 16 PBT of
£242.3m (excluding ground rent sales), this equates to 53% of our FY 16
expectations. However this result was driven by substantially higher
completions, lower selling price, and higher EBIT margins driving better revenues
and EBIT, and much lower profit from associates. The group reported net cash of
£263m (against our expectation of £50m). Management has reiterated its target
of 2016-18 PBT of £2bn. 3) Is there enough reassurance on the London market?
Within the statement Berkeley reports ‘good underlying demand in a stable
operating environment’ with forward sales of £3.1bn (up from £2.959m at FY 15
results). However further questions will need to be asked on the Chairman’s
view of the Autumn statement: ‘concerned that the continued change to
property taxation may well result in unintended consequences’

11:21 am
BE

FT rehashes Sky sale story from October

BE

Let's talk about those changes. International TV is seen as a growth area,
and most believe you're going to finally buy the rest of Sky that you don't
already own. JAMES The Sky businesses, we've only just brought them all
together into one big European platform [Sky Plc]. That integration is going
really well. The company is moving at a very fast pace and has grown in
value enormously. We've also been clear that over time, having 40 percent
of an unconsolidated asset is not an end state that is natural for us. Right
now, we're 100 percent focused on supporting the company to get this
integration going and get it done for the business to move forward, so there
are no plans on the agenda right now. (Source: Hollywood Reporter)

BE

NOMURA VIEW: The FT caries a story yesterday which takes a quote from
an interview with the sons of Rupert Murdoch in the October edition of the
Hollywood reporter. James Murdoch talking about 40% of Sky not being a
natural endstate for Fox does not indicate whether Fox would like to buy the
rest or sell. Our view is that if there was a sale it could be to another
media/telecom company or as a spin-off of Sky shares to Fox holders rather
than a placing on the market, which would be valued at c.GBP7.6bn and so
too large and risky. This could result in discounted receipts for Fox
shareholders.

Anglo will host a 2hr investor presentation on 8-Dec. We expect CEO/ CFO to update on
the progress with strategy and to set out new measures to improve performance &
strengthen the balance sheet. We expect Anglo to move to a pay-out dividend policy,
cutting H2 dividend to close to zero (UBSe 3c/sh), and to update production and capex
guidance out to FY18; we see modest downside to Kumba & Diamond production, with
capex likely to be trimmed (FY16 tgt $3.7bn). We expect Anglo to discuss challenges in
diamonds and reassure it still expects proceeds of $3bn from divestments vs $2.2bn to date. We expect Anglo to meaningfully step up its cost saving target of $1.5bn over 18m
to end-16 given market conditions.

BE

Here's the upshot.

11:47 am
BE

We downgrade to EW as we reflect on 1) slower UK RevPAR growth, 2) deteriorating
leading indicators and 3) reduced corporate capex expectations from our
economists. While Whitbread remains for us a high quality long-term growth story
with a compelling TSR, our positive view had in part been predicated on our belief
that RevPAR growth could beat consensus given the various datapoints we track. We
now believe these indicators may be delivering the opposite message. As such we
now consider the shares to be more ‘fairly valued’ than ‘cheap’ on a 12-m view.
Additionally we are cautious going into the Q3 IMS on 10th Dec. While Q3 overall
should see good c5% RevPAR growth (helped by the Rugby World Cup), we believe
the RevPAR exit rate is somewhat concerning. Our tracking model shows a
slowdown in UK regional RevPAR growth to 2.2% in Nov vs c4.2% in Sept (last clean
month). London also turned negative. We have cut EPS by 1.5% in 16/17 leaving us
c1.5% below consensus. The cuts reflect lower RevPAR growth (consistent with our
economists’ corporate capex projections) and restaurants LFLs. We cut our PT to
5200p due to these revisions as well as a lower EBITDA multiple assumption of 12.5x
17E for PI. The stock trades on 18.3x cal 16e PE (long-term avg of 15x). The PEG stands at 1.5x – now in line with the sector.

BE

• Short-term RevPAR blip or the beginning of a slower RevPAR environment? The
datapoints we track have been getting weaker. The Services PMI, Deloitte CFO
survey and UK business confidence survey - all of which have been good leading
indicators for regional RevPAR - have slowed. Meanwhile the biggest surprise in
the Q3 GDP revision came from business investment which contracted by 1.9%
q/q. Our economists have cut their corporate capex forecasts and now expect
3.8% growth in 2016 vs 5% previously. We are still 20% behind peak in UK
regional real RevPAR and as long as the economy continues to grow at a modest
pace, we should see RevPAR growth continue but the recent datapoints point to a
more muted growth rate than we have seen for Whitbread over recent years.
• Q3 Preview: We expect Q3 RevPAR c+5% (vs 3.9% Q2) and LFLs +c7% (c2%
better than RevPAR due to extensions). We expect 5% Costa LFLs (vs 4% Q2) on
an easier comp of +5.2% vs. Q2 15 +7.3%. Restaurants - we expect LFLs + c1%.

11:50 am
PM

PM

PM

Here's Guillaume Menuet of Citi

11:51 am
PM

Has Draghi Lost His Mojo? ECB Hawks Spoil the Christmas Party

PM

ECB cuts the deposit rate, leaves other rates unchanged — The Governing
Council (GC) cut the interest rate on the deposit facility by 10bp to -0.3%. All other
rates (refi and marginal) were left unchanged. On the refi rate, President Draghi
argued that lowering it would not achieve much as all market rates are determined
by the level of the deposit rate. During the Q&A, he deflected a number of questions
as to whether the deposit rate was at the lower bound, describing the new -30bp
level as being “adequate” and highlighted the effectiveness of the ECB’s monetary
policy in delivering a noticeable easing in financial conditions. The main problem, of
course, was the adverse market reaction – which will partly offset today’s easing.

PM

Four additional measures were taken — In addition to the depo rate cut, the GC
extended the APP (with a new Mar-17 soft-end date, a reinvestment strategy, and
also by broadening the scope of eligible assets to include regional/local government
bonds). It also communicated on the main refi operations and 3-month LTROs, by
confirming that these would be conducted as fixed rate tender procedures, with full
allotment for as long as necessary, and at least until the end of 2017.

11:52 am
PM

Easy monetary policy stance will be maintained — The GC underwhelmed
expectations, with a modest depo cut (we expected -20bp) and no expansion of
monthly purchases (€60bn/month). It also failed to live up to the very dovish rhetoric
developed by a number of board members recently. Yet, Mr. Draghi reiterated that
the APP “provides sufficient flexibility in terms of adjusting its size, composition and
duration”, stressing that the GC will continue to closely monitor the outlook for price
stability. He also recalled that all instruments are available and indicated that more
work would take place in the spring to “adjust some technical parameters”,
expressing his confidence that the GC would be able to meet its inflation mandate.

PM

What next? The modest extra policy stimulus and reinvestment strategy will
probably be enough for the 2018 mid-point (in the Mar-16 staff projections) to be
around 1.8-1.9%, broadly in line with the ECB’s target. However, we maintain the
view that headline inflation will probably undershoot the GC’s baseline again in
coming quarters/years. We therefore still see further easing, most likely through two
more deposit rate cuts (taking it to -75bp in the course of 2016), a further six-month
extension of purchases, and probably with a step-up [+€15bn] in monthly purchases
at some stage. We suspect that the data (modest growth, persistent low-flation) will
lead the doves to gradually re-assert their dominance of the GC.

PM

Communications policy — a new communication policy is now in place, implying
no speeches on the topic of monetary policy or meetings with market participants in
the seven days before a monetary policy setting meeting. Let’s see what Mr. Draghi
says on Friday, when he delivers a speech in New York @ 16:45 GMT.

11:52 am
PM

Woodford defending his action in Northwest Bio

11:53 am
BE

PM

PM

11:54 am
PM

Given his public profile

PM

Many of these press reports were informed by a public filing we made to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on 24 November 2015, which for our part was driven by our belief in robust and corporate governance, and our responsibility to our investors to protect their investments where we deem it necessary.

The filing called for the appointment of an independent non-executive director to the Board of Northwest and, following this appointment, the convening of a special committee of non-executive directors to investigate recent allegations of financial improprieties and regulatory failure that have been published by at least one anonymous source.

Given the level of coverage, I believe it is appropriate to share my views on the situation with you, to give you the context behind our investment in Northwest.

When my team and I first met with Northwest we were attracted to its technology, which looks to harness the power of the body’s immune system to fight cancer. It’s a broad-based technology for a range of solid tumours and is being trialled in patients who have exhausted all other avenues of cancer treatment.

PM

Our conviction in the technology and early clinical data, supported by globally leading oncology clinicians, is the principal factor in our investment. Our long-term aim is also to help the company get into a position where it can attract the consistent funding it will need to successfully complete a Phase III clinical study and beyond. If the company is going to move into a sustainable position to attract a broader range of investors that, in turn, will give it a runway to complete its clinical trials, it needs to put these allegations to rest once and for all.

What I have said all along, and reiterate today, is that with some early-stage investments not everything will go well. There will be bumps in the road and some won’t make it to a successful destination. It is too early to pass judgement on Northwest but we have hit a bump in the road that needs to be addressed.

We have often talked about how, as active fund managers, we engage with boards to represent the interests of our shareholders. The situation with Northwest is such an example. We remain confident in our approach to early-stage investments across all sectors. Indeed, we have seen some notable success over the past 18 months that have contributed to some positive performance for our investors.

Over the next few weeks, we hope that an investigation of the allegations will begin and I will, of course, keep you up-to-date on developments.
